Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Japanese knotweed spreading in gardens on Lordship lane - being ignored., 6th July
item.description:
There is significant and hazardous Japanese knotweed infestation located in the rear garden of Flat 201A Lordship Lane. This has already spread to the garden of 199A Lordship lane and is continuing to spread rapidly in the direction of Harris Primary Academy. 201A has been neglected for an extended period, leading to the rampant spread of the Japanese knotweed. This invasive plant has now visibly established itself in the garden of the next door property, Flat 199A. The aggressive nature of Japanese knotweed presents a serious risk, including potential structural damage to buildings. Our attempts to contact the property owners of 201A and 199A have been unsuccessful, and the situation continues to worsen. Given the pressing nature of this problem, we urge the Council to promptly investigate and engage with the owner of Flat 201A and 199A to ensure immediate corrective measures are implemented. Without swift action by the council, the japanese knotweed will spread into further surrounding gardens, thereby jeopardising multiple properties if the council takes no action.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 22, Landcroft Road, East Dulwich, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: White Paint Everywhere, 6th July
item.description:
A whole tin of white paint has been emptied in the middle of the footpath, and it looks extremely unsightly. The paint is still wet in places and has been trodden through and cycled over, causing it to spread everywhere, including outside people's homes. It's nearly impossible to avoid stepping in it, which means it is being tracked into our homes on the soles of our shoes.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Kibworth Street, Oval, London
Report on FixMyStreet
